Description: Head of female terracotta figure wearing her hair in 'melon style', following Tanagra types. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white coating and red paint on hair. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational between the 3rd to 2nd century BC and possibly later. Parallels from Egypt include early 3rd century BC (Török 1995, pl.114, no.21), early 2nd century BC example (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.2.6, no.12) and late 3rd to 2nd century examples (Fischer 1994, no.104). Both NA542 and NA547 are similar to Ptolemaic examples from Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl. 30. 97; Petrie 1910, pl.44.155) for hairstyle. Gutch dates this example to the 2nd century BC (Gutch in Hogarth 1898-9, 85, no.88). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Fischer, J. 1994. ‘Griechisch-Römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen’. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Petrie, W.M.F. 1909. The palace of Apries. Memphis volume II. London: School of Archaeology in Egypt. Petrie, W.M.F. 1910. Meydum and Memphis volume III. London, School of Archaeology in Egypt. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 85, no. 88)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.405) (Phase 1)
